output.title: The Rise and Fall of Blockbuster: How Netflix Changed Entertainment Forever
output.caption: A tale of two titans in the world of entertainment.
output.resume: In this episode, we explore how Netflix disrupted the traditional video rental industry, led by a once-great giant named Blockbuster.

scenes.script: Once upon a time, in an era before streaming, there was a video rental empire called Blockbuster.
scenes.image_prompt: Archive footage of bustling Blockbuster stores

scenes.script: I remember as a kid, every Friday night we'd go to Blockbuster. It was like a treasure hunt for movies.
scenes.image_prompt: Young David in front of Blockbuster store

scenes.script: Blockbuster wasn't just about renting videos, it was an experience. The smell of new DVDs, the endless aisles... it was magic.
scenes.image_prompt: Lucy in front of Blockbuster shelves

scenes.script: But as with all empires, change was on the horizon. A small startup called Netflix was about to shake things up.
I got my first Netflix disc in the mail around 2001. It was like magic! No more driving, no late fees... it was the future.
scenes.image_prompt: First Netflix disc in the mail

scenes.script: Remember when we used to have to wait for the postman? Now it's instant. That's what Netflix did. They made waiting obsolete.
Blockbuster, however, was slow to react. They laughed off the idea of mailing DVDs, underestimating the power of convenience.
By 2010, I hadn't set foot in a Blockbuster for years. The writing was on the wall.
And then, one by one, the stores started closing. It was sad, but it was progress too.
Today, Blockbuster is but a memory, a relic of a time before streaming. But its legacy lives on in every binge-watch session.
